## What is R Markdown

>- Framework for creating dynamic documents, reports and presentations
>- A tool for integration of R-code execution results into your document

. . .

<center>
<img src="images/RMarkdownOutputFormats.png" alt="" style="width: 300px; height: 300px;"/>
</center>

## Why do we need it?

>- To ensure reproducibility of the results
>- To convert the .Rmd file into different formats
    + HTML
    + PDF
    + MS Word (ODT, RTF)
    + Markdown
    + Presentations: ioslides, reveal.js, Slidy, Beamer
    + Website templates
>- Easy to write and format your documents
>- To share open code, ideas, algotirhms and research results

## Reproducible research and collaboration

>- [Paper in "Nature"](http://www.nature.com/news/1-500-scientists-lift-the-lid-on-reproducibility-1.19970): more than 70% of respondents can not reproduce their collegues' results
>- And it gets worse:
    + More data
    + Complex data analysis schemes
    + Models and algorithms need a lot of fine tuning
    + Traditional journal paper format is not enough anymore
>- [Ropensci reproducibility guide](http://ropensci.github.io/reproducibility-guide/)

## An introduction to Rmarkdown: Inline code

>- Simplest stuff: insert the result as text inside a string
>- Syntaxis: backtick ("`") - "r" - space - R-code - backtick
>- Example: "The theorem is proven under the assumption pi equals `` `r knitr::inline_expr('ceiling(pi)')` ``."
>- Result: "The theorem is proven under the assumption pi equals `r ceiling(pi)`."

## An introduction to Rmarkdown: Code chunks

>- The basic way to insert code
>- Every chunkаждый кусок can be tuned separately using options
>- Chunk may print something out, draw a plot or have no output

## An introduction to Rmarkdown: Chunk syntaxis

```{r, echo=FALSE, comment=""}
cat(c("```{r}",
      "head(iris)",
      "```"), 
    sep='\n')
```

. . .

```{r}
head(iris)
```

## An introduction to Rmarkdown: Option echo=FALSE

>- You can put _options_ for a chunk in figure brackets
>- By default both code and results are shown
>- Option `echo=FALSE` supresses printing the code:

. . .

```{r, echo=FALSE, comment=""}
cat(c("```{r, echo=FALSE}",
      "(1:10)^3",
      "```"), 
    sep='\n')
```

. . .

```{r, echo=FALSE}
(1:10)^3
```

## An introduction to Rmarkdown: Layout

>- `**Bold** __font__` --> **Bold** __font__
>- `*Italic* _font_` --> *Italic* _font_
>- Monospeced text `` `sum(x)` `` --> `sum(x)`
>- Upper and lower indices `A^2^~i~` --> A^2^~i~
>- `~~Strikeout~~ text` --> ~~Strikeout~~ text
>- Symbols escape: `\* \_ \\ \$` --> \* \_ \\ \$ 
>- Autocorrection of dash and long dash: `-- ---` --> -- ---

## Main elements Markdown

>- Headers: `# Header 1` -- `###### Header 6`
>- Hyperlink: `<https://www.github.com/nvolkova>` --> <https://www.github.com/nvolkova>
>- Hyperlink in text: `[My github](https://www.github.com/nvolkova)` --> [My github](https://www.github.com/nvolkova)
>- <http://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/rmarkdown-cheatsheet-2.0.pdf>

## Latex support

>- To biold a pdf ypu need to install $\TeX$ (MiKTeX, TeX Live)
>- `$\hat{\beta} = (X^T X)^{-1} X^T y$` --> $\hat{\beta} = (X^T X)^{-1} X^T y$
>- `$$i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} ... $$` --> $$i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\Psi(\mathbf{r},t) = \hat H \Psi(\mathbf{r},t)$$
>- All the functions available in $\TeX$ (settings, packages, macros и т.д.)
>- Formulas are shown correctly in HTML thanks to MathJax
